1. Introduction

This page describes how to rebuild the various components of the CoreData API.

2. Rebuilding CoreData C++ API

  • Compiling CoreData C++ API

3. Rebuilding Bindings

The steps involved for rebuilding the CoreData C# or Python Bindings:

  1. Run SWIG to generate C++ wrapper source code and target language (C# or Python) source
  2. Compile the SWIG generated C++ wrapper source and link it against the CoreData C++ API, to produce a C wrapper shared library.
  3. C# only: Compile/link the generated C# into an assembly.

This section explains these steps in detail.

3.1 SWIG

SWIG (http://www.swig.org/) is a software development tool that connects C/C++ code with a variety of other programming languages. The CoreData API employs SWIG to generate the C# and Python bindings.

SWIG processes the original C++ source code (in coredata/) and a *.i file (in swigcoredata/) which defines the transformation to the target language. It outputs a C++ wrapper source file, and target language source file.

In order to use SWIG with CoreData:

  • Download and install SWIG 1.3.38. (Earlier version of SWIG are not supported.)
  • Add the directory containing the swig executable to your path.
    • E.g on Windows: SET PATH=PATH%;C:\Program Files\swigwin-1.3.38

3.2 C# Bindings

Running SWIG

The run-swig batch file requires the major and minor version number to pass to swig for determining the name of the wrapper DLL.

 cd cscoredata/src/
 run-swig.bat 3.2

Output files:

  • eod/eod_wrap.cpp
  • eod/*.cs
  • eodio/eodio_wrap.cpp
  • eodio/*.cs
  • eodutils/eodutils_wrap.cpp
  • eodutils/*.cs

Generating Bindings
From a Visual Studio 2008 command prompt: 

 cd cscoredata/src
 nmake -f Makefile.win32_ia32sse2_vc90 clean all
 cd cscoredata/examples
 nmake -f Makefile.win32_ia32sse2_vc90 clean all

3.3 Python Bindings

Running SWIG

 cd pycoredata/src/
 run-swig.bat

Generating Bindings
From a Visual Studio 2008 command prompt: 

 cd pycoredata/src
 nmake -f Makefile.win32_ia32sse2_vc90 clean all
